qas.question: What is another name for people who recently converted to Islam?
Who argued that the Umayyads regarded Islam as a particularly aristocratic faith?
What sorts of families did the Umayyads show favor to?
Which caliphate was not marked by territorial expansion?
Who favored the rights of newly converted Muslims?
Who did the mawali show favor to?
Who had a more universalist conception of Islam than their rivals?

context: The <b3_0>Umayyad<b3_0/> caliphate was marked both by territorial expansion and by the administrative and cultural problems that such expansion created. Despite some notable exceptions, the <b4_0><b6_0>Umayyads<b6_0/><b4_0/> tended to favor the rights of the <a2_0><b5_0>old Arab<a2_0/> families<b5_0/>, and in particular their own, over those of newly converted Muslims (<a0_0>mawali<a0_0/>). Therefore, they held to a less universalist conception of Islam than did many of their rivals. As <a1_0>G.R. Hawting<a1_0/> has written, "Islam was in fact regarded as the property of the conquering aristocracy."
